description.plain:
Migos is a rap group from Lawrenceville, Georgia, formed in 2008. The trio consists of Quavo (real name Quavious Marshall), Takeoff (real name Kirshnik Ball) and Offset (real name Kiari Cephus). The Migos are relatives: members Quavo and Takeoff are uncle and nephew, and members Quavo and Offset are cousins.

They are most known for their hit songs “Versace”, that became even more successful after Drake released a remix of it, and “Bad and Boujee.” Despite this, “Bando” was their first hit song.

They have released numerous mixtapes since 2011, most notably Young Rich Niggas, No Label 2, Rich Nigga Timeline & Young Rich Niggas 2.

They released their debut album Yung Rich Nation on July 31st, 2015, their second studio album, Culture, was released on January 27th, 2017. The group’s 3rd album, Culture II, was released on January 26th, 2018.

With the release of Culture II, Migos tied The Beatles for most simultaneous Hot 100 songs by a group on the Billboard chart with 14.

description.plain:
“Bad and Boujee" is a trap anthem about making money and spending time with women who have expensive taste. “Boujee” is an intentional misspelling of “bougie,” which is slang for bourgeois, and refers to the materialism of society’s middle class.

This Metro Boomin-produced track marks the first collaboration between Northside/North Atlanta’s Migos, minus Takeoff, and Philly’s Lil Uzi Vert.

“Bad and Boujee” is Migos' highest-charting track yet, as well as their first to top the Billboard Hot 100 chart.

songs.title: Versace (Remix)

description.plain: After this Zaytoven-produced beat was originally taken by Plies for "Bitch a Hoe" and then to Soulja Boy Tell ‘Em for "OMG Pt. 2", it landed on Migos’ Y.R.N (Young Rich Niggas) Mixtape in the form of "Versace." When the song blew up and came to the attention of Drake, he rapped a verse to create this remix and made the song even more famous.

songs.title: T-Shirt

description.plain:
Migos rock fur in an icy new music video, the third single from Culture, following the viral “Bad and Boujee” and “Call Casting.”

The track features each member of Migos rapping their own unique brand of braggadocio, using a stop-and-start flow. In the chorus, Quavo interpolates lyrics from late Atlanta legend Shawty Lo’s verse on “I’m Da Man” by D4L.

body.plain:
Migos rock fur in an icy new music video, the third single from Culture, following the viral “Bad and Boujee” and “Call Casting.”

The track features each member of Migos rapping their own unique brand of braggadocio, using a stop-and-start flow. In the chorus, Quavo interpolates lyrics from late Atlanta legend Shawty Lo’s verse on “I’m Da Man” by D4L.

songs.title: Slippery

description.plain:
On “Slippery,” the Migos team up with fellow Atlantan Gucci Mane for a song about drugs, jewelry, and Quavo’s aunts and uncles.

The track features a beat produced by Deko and OG Parker that sounds very different from the usual Migos beat.

This is not the first time the Migos have featured Gucci on their tracks. He has appeared before on tracks such as 2016’s “Now” and 2013’s “Dennis Rodman.” Additionally, Migos are thought to have inspired Gucci’s latest album title, Drop Top Wop.

description.plain:
In “Walk It Talk It,” Migos and Drake take jabs at fake people around them who can’t walk the life that they talk about.

With the success that each Migos member and Drake have enjoyed, they can truly flash material possessions that others may struggle to afford.

songs.title: Stir Fry

description.plain:
“Stir Fry” is the second single off Culture II. In the Pharrell-produced song, Migos drop fast food references and flaunt their success.

This marks the first time in a long time that the trio strayed away from their signature Atlanta trap sound and rap over a poppier beat.

According to Quavo, they ran into Pharrell in Los Angeles when the N.E.R.D frontman stepped into one of their studio sessions with a “pack” of beats from 2008 earmarked for the Atlanta trio:

We was in the studio in L.A. and he was in the next room. We had been running into each other, we’ve been cool, but he was over there working and he just stepped in because we just walk in everybody’s sessions and it’s love, and go to work. And Pharrell had, like, three or four beats, but the pack was from 2008, like, the old hard drive. He had the old pack. He said he was waiting on this moment. The genie way.

The beat was originally intended for an unreleased T.I. song. Twitter user Erik Anderson pinpointed the track as “Trap Nigga Hustle,” which was recorded two years prior to the Atlanta rapper’s 2014 album Paperwork. T.I. mentioned it during an interview with DJ Whoo Kid and previewed the instrumental in a Vevo segment about his car collection:

https://youtu.be/Yr4TTzI2xgA

songs.title: Kelly Price

description.plain:
Migos and Travis Scott give us a peek into their materialistic women-and-drug-filled lifestyle.

Kelly Price is an R&B singer; you may recognize her feature on “Ultralight Beam.” Migos and Travis Scott continue their trend of name-dropping R&B singers, such as Brian McKnight  into their songs and lyrics.

Travis & Quavo have also collaborated on the album Huncho Jack, Jack Huncho

songs.title: Narcos

description.plain:
On “Narcos,” Migos pay homage to South American cities, culture, and drug lords. The lyrics describe drug dealing whilst drawing several similarities with the popular Netflix original series of the same name, Narcos, which is centered around Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar.

Whilst the Migos' make multiple references to Latin countries, the official sample is taken from “Espoir” by Les Difficiles de Pétion-Ville, a song from Haïti.

songs.title: Deadz

description.plain:
On “Deadz,” the Migos team up with fellow Georgia native 2 Chainz for a somewhat majestic song about counting money.

“Deadz” refers to U.S. currency, which features the faces of dead presidents, as well as Benjamin Franklin, who is also dead.

2 Chainz has previously collaborated with  Quavo on his 2016 hit “Good Drank.”

songs.title: Cocoon

description.plain:
On “Cocoon” the Migos sing-rap with the help of auto-tune, over a soft, key-driven beat from Cheeze.

The single was officially through iTunes on May 19th, 2016.

BET Tweeted the official video for the song on June 24, 2016:

songs.title: BBO (Bad Bitches Only)

description.plain:
“BBO (Bad Bitches Only)” is a all about sharing Migos and 21 Savage’s love for women who are down to have sex with them and are truly “bad.”

This song was one of the most anticipated track on Culture II, before people even knew of the title. This was due to a post Quavo had on Instagram, where he listed Kanye West as an additional producer.



It was rumored that West was an executive producer of the entire album, but Quavo shot those rumors down before people got too excited.

songs.title: What the Price

description.plain:
Released on January 20th, 2017, “What the Price” is the fourth single off of Migos‘ highly anticipated sophomore album, Culture.

Borrowing from their history of dealing drugs, Migos discuss the fluctuation of drug prices and their spending habits.

Although “What the Price” has not received the wild success of “Bad and Boujee” and “T-Shirt”, the single  is a very worthy trap anthem, drawing off samples from Lil Bibby’s “Steph”, and Swipey’s  “Intro”.

body.plain:
Released on January 20th, 2017, “What the Price” is the fourth single off of Migos‘ highly anticipated sophomore album, Culture.

Borrowing from their history of dealing drugs, Migos discuss the fluctuation of drug prices and their spending habits.

Although “What the Price” has not received the wild success of “Bad and Boujee” and “T-Shirt”, the single  is a very worthy trap anthem, drawing off samples from Lil Bibby’s “Steph”, and Swipey’s  “Intro”.

songs.title: Gang Gang

description.plain:
Unknown to many, Quavo, Offset, and Takeoff are related. Quavo is Takeoff’s uncle, and Offset is Quavo’s cousin.

Migos is their own gang, and they do everything together. Whether it be posting up smoking a fat blunt, or pulling up at an event suited up looking fresh just like they did at the 2017 Met Gala (see photo below), they are always doing it together, repping Migos as a team.  Their support for one another was clear during a 2017 BET awards interview with Complex News when Joe Budden abruptly left up while DJ Akademiks was interviewing Takeoff.  On their track “Ice Tray” they target Budden specifically saying:

If a nigga hatin', call him Joe Budden (pussy)

Proving that a slight against one of them is a slight against all of them.

songs.title: Culture

description.plain:
“Culture” is the titular and first song off the Migos sophomore album. The song covers popular Migos topics such as their wealth and spending habits, along with drugs and violence.

Given the tense of some of the lyrics, it’s thought the song may have been intended for release on DJ Khaled’s 2016 LP Major Key.

songs.title_with_featured: White Sand (Ft. Big Sean, Travis Scott & Ty Dolla $ign)

description.plain:
Migos recruit frequent collaborator Travis Scott – who also made an appearance on Culture –  as well as Big Sean and Ty Dolla $ign to assist them on this star-studded banger.

The title refers to cocaine, with the three going on to further wax lyrical about doing drugs, driving fancy cars, and wearing expensive jewelry.  They also reference their experiences with fame.

songs.title: Dab of Ranch

description.plain:
Migos bring their fans a very catchy jingle to their edition of Rap Snacks. The trio is featured on the Sour Cream edition.

CEO James Lindsay confirmed that Migos will be releasing “Dab of Ranch” as a single in a commercial alongside new merchandise.

https://www.instagram.com/p/BNaqCmlA50y/

Soon after, on January 26, 2017, Migos themselves released a snippet of the finished song:

https://twitter.com/IamAkademiks/status/824804123069538304

On February 8th, Migos released the song in its entirety via Spotify:

https://open.spotify.com/track/3lNfezSWDZIdt6XMwyNCJi

songs.title: Big on Big

description.plain: “Big on Big” covers the major success of Migos in the past years. Their success is reaching new heights with songs like “Bad and Boujee” and previously released work, going from “big” to “bigger.” Migos is asking other rappers in the scene how they are planning to achieve the same success as they did.

songs.title: Supastars

description.plain:
“Supastars” is the third promotional single released before the album and the 2nd Track on Culture II, following “MotorSport” and “Stir Fry.”

Throughout the song, each Migos member describes the wild and lavish superstar lifestyle they now live due to their immense wealth and fame.

The song was premiered via Beats 1 Radio on Zane Lowe’s show just four days before the album’s release.

songs.title: Out Yo Way

description.plain:
On the final track of Culture, the Migos take a minute to recognize the pretty little ladies that go the extra mile to make them happy.

Rather than adopting the stereotypical view of women in rap music, the Migos offer to repay the women that have stood by them through thick and thin.

songs.title: Higher We Go (Intro)

description.plain:
“Higher We Go” is the opening song of the highly anticipated sequel to their 2017 album Culture.

In the song, the trio introduce the notion that despite how high they are (both off of making weed and being at the top of the hip-hop food chain by commanding the game) they will continue to rise up as kings of the genre, and the culture.

They are willing to sweat and bleed making beats and spitting bars because they feel obligated to drive the entire hip hop industry in the right direction.

The original instrumental, produced by Metro Boomin, was used in SG Tip’s 2017 single “No Brain.” This track’s instrumental features added production by DJ Durel and Quavo.

songs.full_title: Give No Fxk by Migos (Ft. Travis Scott & Young Thug)
songs.title: Give No Fxk
songs.title_with_featured: Give No Fxk (Ft. Travis Scott & Young Thug)

description.plain:
On “Give No Fxk,“ Atlanta stars Migos reunite with frequent collaborators Travis Scott and Young Thug for a braggadocios trap anthem. The song marks the five artists' first appearance all together on a song and is expected to serve as the lead single off of the last installment of Migos' Culture trilogy, Culture III, which has been announced to be released in 2020.

The collaboration was first teased on November 11, 2019, in an Instagram live stream before being debuted a few hours later at Travis' ASTROWORLD FESTIVAL, alongside Migos and Thug for the first live performance. The song officially released on February 14, 2020, complemented by its Valentine’s Day release date.

songs.title: Emoji a Chain

description.plain:
Quavo, Offest and Takeoff join forces with producer Metro Boomin to make the seventh song of Culture II.

Migos have previously worked on music with Metro Boomin. The most famous and prominent song is their chart topper, “Bad and Boujee” featuring Lil Uzi Vert.

description.plain:
On “Need It,” Migos connects with YoungBoy Never Broke Again to rap about their violent lifestyles and how they will protect themselves.

YB first teased the song in a video posted on his Twitter on January 14, 2020. It showed him and Offset rapping back and forth recording their contributions to the track.

songs.title: Too Playa

description.plain:
2 Chainz and Migos feel that they are “Too Playa” meaning that they are too good at what they do. They get so many women, so many nice cars, and make so much money, their lifestyles are almost too luxurious.

They brag about all of the drugs they do, the expensive jewelry they have bought, and the beautiful women they have has sex with.

Migos and 2 Chainz have collaborated in the past on the banger “Deadz”.
